美国参谋长联席会议周五表示，韩国已从海上打捞上月朝鲜发射第一颗军事卫星失败的火箭部件。

军方表示，该部件于周四晚上打捞​​上来，并补充说正在继续搜索朝鲜声称是太空运载火箭的其他物体。

5 月 31 日，朝鲜试图将其第一颗间谍卫星发射到太空，但最终以助推器和有效载荷坠入大海而告终。

在火箭坠入西海岸的鱼清岛附近海域后，韩国一直在进行打捞行动。

韩国军方发布的照片​​显示了一个巨大的圆柱形物体。

军方在一份声明中说：“打捞上来的物体将由包括国防发展局在内的专家组织进行彻底分析。”

官员们表示，日本正准备向菲律宾提供军事援助，以帮助确保海上通道安全并保卫台湾的西翼，深化安全关系可能使日本军队自第二次世界大战以来首次重返那里。

在从几十年的和平主义中倒退时，东京担心菲律宾是从日本列岛延伸到印度尼西亚的岛链中的薄弱环节，船只必须通过该岛链进出太平洋。

日本军方最担心的是中国对邻国台湾的攻击可能引发更广泛的冲突，日本首相岸田文雄警告称，今天的乌克兰可能成为明天的东亚。为了帮助解决这个问题，东京在 4 月份表示，它将向志同道合的国家提供军事援助，包括雷达，官员们表示，这将帮助菲律宾填补防御缺口。

“向菲律宾提供雷达非常有用，因为这意味着我们可以共享有关巴士海峡的信息，”退役海军上将河野胜俊说，他指的是菲律宾和台湾之间的水道。它被认为是在西太平洋和有争议的南中国海之间航行的船只的咽喉要道。

三名参与国家安全战略规划的日本政府官员告诉路透社，华盛顿正在向日本提供建议，因为它与菲律宾有着密切的军事关系。然而，一位人士表示，援助工作是日本的倡议，而不是美国所要求的任何东西。

由于此事的敏感性，这些官员拒绝透露姓名。

“我们正在选择可用于海上监测和安全的设备。我们还不知道具体是什么，”日本外务省发言人说。

菲律宾外交部表示，无法立即就日本的安全援助或接待日本军队发表评论。

美国总统乔·拜登的国家安全顾问杰克·沙利文将于周五在东京与日本和菲律宾的国家安全顾问秋叶武夫和阿野爱德华多会面，这是讨论安全合作的一系列定期会议中的第一次。

放宽规则

日本军事援助的范围受到自行实施的致命设备出口禁令的限制。

日本首相岸田文雄去年 12 月宣布了一项史无前例的五年军备计划，将在五年内将国防开支翻番，承诺重新审查这一限制。

预计未来几个月将放宽出口规定，但随着工业经济体帮助乌克兰的压力越来越大，东京已开始测试这些限制。

上个月乌克兰总统泽伦斯基访问日本参加七国集团领导人峰会后，岸田捐赠了军用卡车和其他车辆。东京还告诉美国，它可以在日本购买工业炸药，用于制造运往乌克兰的炮弹，并可能自行向美国提供炮弹，从而为基辅腾出补给。

曾担任日本自卫队 (SDF) 司令的川野说，日本对菲律宾的军事援助“将逐步扩大，我希望它会改变，包括反舰导弹等致命武器”联合参谋部任期五年至 2019 年。

Kawano 和接受路透社采访的政府官员预测，马尼拉可以让日本进入其军事基地，就像对待美国一样，允许日本自卫队飞机在南中国海巡逻。日本可以从大约 100 公里外的与那国岛监测台湾以东的海域。

2 月，菲律宾总统小费迪南德·马科斯 (Ferdinand Marcos Jr.) 和岸田在东京同意两国军队将合作救灾。

在那次会议上，岸田还向马科斯承诺提供 6000 亿日元（43 亿美元）的发展援助和私人投资，在此之前，日本战斗机于 12 月首次访问菲律宾，并举行了一系列高级别军事会议。日本在 3 月观察了美菲军事演习，本月他们的海岸警卫队首次一起训练。

专家说，所有这一切都可能成为互惠准入协议 (RAA) 的前身，该协议将允许两国在彼此的领土上部署军队。三位日本政府官员中的另一位表示，如果马尼拉接受这样的协议——东京与英国和澳大利亚签订了 RAA——一项协议可能会在一年内达成。

“自从政府更迭以来，菲律宾一直在发出非常积极的信号，这可能意味着很快达成协议，”日本国家防卫研究所高级研究员石原佑介说。但他表示，日本和美国在与菲律宾的三方会谈中谨慎行事。

“它对与中国的关系很敏感。诀窍是通过讨论经济问题或经济安全而不仅仅是防御来让菲律宾放心，”他说。

Tim Kelly、Sakura Murakami 和 Yukiko Toyoda 在东京的报道； Neil Jerome Morales 在马尼拉的补充报道。由 Gerry Doyle 编辑; Fri, 16 Jun 2023 00:18:07 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/japan-hopes-shore-up-philippines-defence-amid-taiwan-conflict-fears-2023-06-16/ https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/japan-hopes-shore-up-philippines-defence-amid-taiwan-conflict-fears-2023-06-16/Tim Kelly, Sakura Murakami, Yukiko Toyoda日本菲律宾/国防（分析，PIX） Cheap 'like cabbage' apartments in some Chinese cities draw buyers, and cautionSummary:
  • 中国小城市的公寓在价格暴跌后找到买家
  • 小城市被视为“平躺”或退休的地方
  • 购买反映出整个经济的信心不足--分析师
  • 中国最新新房价格、房地产投资数据悲观

北京居民胡永伟在中国中部小城市鹤壁购买了十多套公寓，总价约为 31,000 美元，押注这些公寓在经济上将比其他投资回报更高。

胡先生购买的大多是大约 30 年前建造的两居室或三居室公寓，他本月花费 18,000 元人民币（2,528 美元）购买了他在鹤壁的第 15 处房产，过去两年那里的房价暴跌。

“这些公寓卖得很便宜，就像白菜一样，”这位 39 岁的老人说，并补充说他的家人在股市上的糟糕经历让他避开了股票。

房地产经纪人表示，中国东部的淮南和乳山，以及西南部的​​个旧等较小城市的廉价公寓也在被购买，主要是居住在这些地区以外的人。

这些交易表明，买家开始将注意力转向中国的小城市，在更广泛的行业低迷和整体经济低迷的情况下，经过多年下跌后，这些城市的房价在全国处于最低水平。

虽然中小城市的购房规模不足以影响中国庞大的房地产市场，也没有交易量数据，但它们表明，受危机打击的行业的一小部分正在显示出生机。

这些交易出现之际，中国房地产市场的景象正变得越来越暗淡。数据显示，5 月份新房价格上涨速度放缓， 房地产投资跌幅为 20 多年来最快。

对于有能力重返市场的买家来说，小城市二手公寓的低价难以抗拒。

胡先生为他在鹤壁的一套公寓支付了低得惊人的 1000 元人民币（不含税费）。根据中国最大的房地产平台之一安居客的数据，该市部分地区的房价较 2021 年的峰值下跌了 27%。

同样，淮南、乳山和个旧部分地区的价格比最高价低了 24%。

相比之下，在截至今年 5 月的六年时间里，北京二手房的平均价格为数万元，其价格仅下跌了 1.5%，而在二线城市重庆，价格下跌了根据路透社基于安居客数据的计算，五年内增长略高于 10%。

“买家不是本地人”

房地产经纪人表示，小城市的买家大多来自外地。他们的范围从不想住在公寓里的投机者，到寻找便宜地方“躺着”的年轻人，再到寻求负担得起的退休生活的人。

在淮南，“大多数买家都不是本地人”，一位因未获授权对媒体发言而只透露姓氏的代理人赵说。 “由于大城市生活成本高，年轻人来这里买便宜的房子，躺平。”

在乳山，经纪人刘勇说，大多数买家来自中国其他地方，年龄在 40 到 50 岁之间，希望在海边安家。个旧的一位中介表示，买家的目标是搬到那里，因为这里的生活成本较低。

不过，鉴于更广泛的迹象表明世界第二大经济体正努力从 COVID-19 封锁中复苏，分析师不愿从这些小城市的购房情况中得出乐观的结论。

消费者信心仍低于过去二十年设定的范围。国内需求疲软，因为消费者和公司更愿意偿还债务而不是投资。青年失业率创历史新高，超过 20%。

华宝信托经济学家聂文说：“有这么多人在较小的城市购买廉价公寓这一事实反映出谨慎。” “人们对自己未来的收入没有信心。”

($1 = 7.1643 人民币)

根据得克萨斯州州长 Greg Abbott 签署成为法律的一项措施，得克萨斯州所有国家资助的学院和大学将不得不关闭其多元化、公平和包容办公室。

得克萨斯州参议院的发起人之一称该法律是该国对高等教育多元化办公室最重要的禁令，人们普遍预计本月晚些时候美国最高法院将禁止学院和大学将种族视为一个种族问题。他们录取决定的因素。

根据雅培周三签署的德克萨斯州法律，任何不证明其遵守该措施的公立学院或大学将无法使用分配给它的州资金。

它还要求州政府官员在 2029 年之前每两年进行一次研究，以评估该法律对按种族分类的学生的影响。它将着眼于申请率、录取率、入学率、保留率和毕业率，以及平均绩点。法律没有解释进行这些研究的原因。

该法律是得克萨斯州共和党议员和同样是共和党人的雅培的最新一击，批评者抨击多样性、公平和包容性或 DEI 的努力是分裂或反白人的，而支持者则表示他们可以帮助来自不同种族的人背景学会一起工作。

“得克萨斯州正在引领全国，确保我们的校园重新关注多样性的力量，并提倡根据个人的资格、技能和贡献来评判他们的择优方法，”州参议员布兰登·克赖顿 (Brandon Creighton) 是共和党人之一，他是该法案的作者在一份声明中说。

但全国高等教育多元化官员协会主席 Paulette Granberry Russell 在一份声明中表示，该法案的签署标志着“德克萨斯州公立大学所有学生的悲伤时刻”。

拉塞尔写道：“通过取消这些机构的多样性、公平和包容性项目和办公室，德克萨斯州立法者选择优先考虑政治议程，而不是这些学生的成功。”

她说，所有学生，无论种族如何，都可以从多元化的学生群体中受益，她的组织不会停止为德州大学的工作而努力，以提高其可及性和包容性。

Brad Brooks 在得克萨斯州拉伯克市的报道；由 Donna Bryson 和 Leslie Adler 编辑; Thu, 15 Jun 2023 23:44:54 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/us/texas-governor-signs-law-shutting-diversity-offices-public-universities-2023-06-15/ https://www.reuters.com/world/us/texas-governor-signs-law-shutting-diversity-offices-public-universities-2023-06-15/Reuters得克萨斯州种族/ (PIX) BOJ to keep ultra-low rates, focus on Ueda's inflation viewsSummary:
  • 外界普遍认为日本央行维持利率目标不变
  • 预计政策决定 0300-0500GMT
  • 聚焦上田对通胀压力上升的看法
  • 日本央行的许多人更愿意等待工资和全球前景的明朗化

尽管通胀强于预期，但市场普遍预计日本央行周五将维持超宽松货币政策，因为在全球经济增长急剧放缓的情况下，日本央行将重点支持脆弱的经济复苏。

央行也可能保持“耐心”维持大规模刺激措施的承诺不变，以确保日本在工资上涨的同时可持续地实现 2% 的通胀目标。

然而，随着物价上涨出现扩大迹象，市场关注日本央行行长上田一夫是否会在其会后新闻发布会上就通胀超调风险发出更强烈的警告。

日本央行审查是在美联储周三决定暂停加息之后进行的，因为它密切关注过去货币紧缩的滞后经济影响。

在周五结束的为期两天的会议上，外界普遍预计日本央行将维持其 -0.1% 的短期利率目标和根据其收益率曲线控制 (YCC) 政策设定的 10 年期债券收益率上限为 0%。

消息人士告诉路透社，尽管日本央行可能会就全球前景面临的风险发出警告，但它可能会坚持认为，由于大流行后消费回升，日本经济正走向温和复苏。

日本的核心消费者通胀在 4 月份达到 3.4%，在一年多的时间里保持在日本央行的目标之上，保持市场对央行将在今年某个时候逐步淘汰 YCC 的预期。

Ueda 一再排除近期调整 YCC 的可能性，认为近期的成本推动通胀将在今年晚些时候放缓回落至日本央行的目标之下。

但他也表示，如果其通胀预测被证明是错误的，日本央行将“迅速采取行动” ，并指出有迹象表明企业定价行为开始发生变化。

随着公司提供三十年来最大幅度的加薪，日本央行也暗示日本长期的工资停滞时代可能会结束。

日本央行在 5 月份发表的一份学术论文中表示，一旦成本超过某个阈值，通胀和工资增长可能会突然加速 - 一旦工资开始上涨，这种趋势可能会持续下去。

不过，许多日本央行官员目前更愿意按兵不动，仔细审视全球经济发展和企业盈利，以寻找明年工资是否会继续上涨的线索。

日本经济正在从大流行中延迟复苏，第一季度年化增长率为 2.7%，稳健的企业和家庭支出缓和了出口疲软带来的打击。

温尼伯自由新闻报称，周四，一辆半挂卡车撞上一辆通常用于运载老人和残疾人的车辆，导致加拿大草原省份马尼托巴省至少 15 人死亡。

报告称，坠机事故发生在温尼伯以西 170 公里（105 英里）的马尼托巴省西南部的 Carberry 镇附近。如果死亡人数得到确认，这将是加拿大近代历史上最致命的交通事故之一。

加拿大广播公司播放了现场的视频，显示消防员向路边沟渠中一辆着火的白色汽车喷水。它还显示了一辆蓝色卡车的静止图片，前部被撞毁。

温尼伯自由报称，第二辆车由运送老人和残疾人的 Handi-Transit 运营。 CTV 网络还称有 15 人死亡。

加拿大皇家骑警表示，所有可用资源都已部署到现场。马尼托巴省卫生当局表示，“大规模伤亡应对”正在进行中。

马尼托巴警方将于下午 4 点 30 分（格林威治标准时间 2130）向记者作简报。

“听到卡伯里附近发生悲惨事故的消息，我的心都碎了，”曼尼托巴省省长希瑟斯特凡森在推特上说。

2018 年 4 月，在邻近的萨斯喀彻温省，一辆卡车在乡村公路上撞上了一辆运送少年曲棍球队的公共汽车，导致 16 人死亡。卡车司机于 2019 年被判处八年徒刑。

2018 年，Paul Wang 离开他在北京的家，在澳大利亚开始新的生活，他投资 100 万澳元（68 万美元）在一家食品加工企业，希望根据该国的投资签证计划获得永久居留权。

五年过去了，由于政府将有争议的“黄金签证”计划搁置一旁，他对三口之家的希望仍然搁置，导致处理时间过长，使像王这样的富裕移民陷入困境。

“我们没想到会花这么长时间，”44 岁的王说。“我们的生活因此变得一团糟。我们根本无法提前计划所有的不确定性。”

澳大利亚在 2012 年推出商业创新和投资计划 (BIIP) 时，希望富有的企业主、投资者和企业家通过引入资本和推动创新来推动经济发展。

然而，结果并不令人满意。 3 月份发布的政府审查发现，BIIP 移民对经济的贡献低于澳大利亚平均水平，因为尽管这群人很富有，但他们往往年龄较大，而且通过被动投资的资本回报获得的收入较低。

该审查估计 BIIP 持有人一生的经济贡献为 60 万澳元，不到澳大利亚人 160 万澳元的一半。

13 个月前上台后，澳大利亚工党政府将工作重点转移到缓解关键技术工人短缺问题上。部分结果是，大多数 BIIP 永久签证需要近三年的时间来处理，高于之前的平均 12 个月左右，此外还有四到五年的投资周期。

王已经等了21个月。

类似的投资签证计划已在加拿大、英国和新加坡被取消，因为政府认为它们不会创造就业机会，并且可能成为存放投机资金的一种手段。

在 COVID-19 期间，每类澳大利亚签证都出现了积压。随着大流行病的缓解，政府总体上缩短了处理时间，但 3,000 多名 BIIP 持有人及其家人（其中许多是中国人）的等待时间却只增不减。

“人们不会同情”

一些 BIIP 申请者计划于周五在悉尼抗议政府的政策转变，这种情况很少见，因为中国移民基本上会回避公众异议。

当被问及签证延误时，内政部在一封电子邮件声明中表示，政府将根据优先级和计划水平处理所有签证，拒绝就 BIIP 持有人的投诉发表评论。

它表示将在今年晚些时候发布一项新的移民战略，其中将包括“彻底重塑”BIIP 计划。

居住和公民规划公司 Henley & Partners Australia 的董事总经理 Tony Le Nevez 表示，这些延误引起了人们对政府可能会取消 BIIP 计划的担忧，该公司的客户在该国每人至少投资了 500 万澳元。

“我只是认为投资者计划目前不在他们的关注范围之内——他们可能会在未来对其进行彻底改革。与此同时，我认为他们可能只是打开一个小窗口。”

政府计划将 BIIP 的配额从上一财年的 5,000 个签证减少到今年的 1,900 个——不到前几年水平的 20%。

BIIP 持有人表示，鉴于不确定性，他们正在缩减商业投资，推迟人生决定，并在某些情况下出售澳大利亚的房产。一些人表示，他们必须坚持亏损的业务，以保持他们的签证前景，从而错失回报更高的投资。

“永远的等待意味着，即使我的生意亏本经营，我也不能关门大吉继续前进，”在墨尔本拥有一家家具店的中国投资者 Tan 说，他要求只透露姓氏由于隐私问题。他已经等了33个月。

由于签证身份的不确定性，王先生去年放弃了为他的工厂购买更多土地的计划，他说他准备出售他在澳大利亚的资产，明年搬到美国接受女儿的教育。

“我知道很多人不会同情我们——我们是一小群人，”王说。 “但我们没有得到公平对待。”

($1 = 1.4691 澳元)

Stella Qiu 报道；由 Praveen Menon 和 William Mallard 编辑; Thu, 15 Jun 2023 21:08:50 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/australias-visa-overhaul-leaves-chinese-millionaires-limbo-2023-06-15/ https://www.reuters.com/world/australias-visa-overhaul-leaves-chinese-millionaires-limbo-2023-06-15/Stella Qiu澳大利亚中国/百万富翁 (PIX) US government agencies hit in global hacking spree, CNN reports

据美国有线电视新闻网周四报道，一些美国联邦政府机构在一场全球黑客活动中遭到攻击，该活动利用了广泛使用的软件中的一个漏洞。

美国网络安全和基础设施安全局 (CISA) 负责网络安全的执行助理主任埃里克·戈德斯坦 (Eric Goldstein) 告诉 CNN，美国网络安全和基础设施安全局 (CISA) 正在为数个联邦机构提供支持，这些机构的入侵影响了黑客利用的易受攻击的软件。

受影响软件的名称和所谓漏洞的详细信息均未确定。 CISA 没有立即回应路透社的置评请求。美国联邦调查局和美国国家安全局也没有立即回复寻求评论的电子邮件。

流行软件产品中的漏洞一再导致世界各地各种组织的后续违规行为。最近，传输软件 MOVEit 的一个弱点导致 BBC、Boots 和英国航空公司等组织的数据遭到破坏。

目前尚不清楚这些黑客攻击是否与最近宣布的美国政府违规行为有关。

声称对 MOVEit 黑客攻击负责的在线勒索组织 Cl0p 此前曾表示，它不会利用从政府机构获取的任何数据。

“如果你是政府、城市或警察部门，请不要担心，我们删除了你的所有数据，”该组织在其网站上的一份声明中说。

Cl0p 没有立即回复寻求评论的消息。 MOVEit 的制造商 Progress Software Corp (PRGS.O)没有立即回复消息。

美国众议院共和党人周四通过的下一财年政府支出目标低于议长凯文麦卡锡和民主党总统乔拜登商定的水平，与民主党领导的参议院展开斗争，可能再次面临政府关门的风险。

众议院拨款委员会按照党派立场以 33 票对 27 票通过了 10 月 1 日开始的 2024 财年的可自由支配支出水平 1.47 万亿美元。

这比拜登和麦卡锡谈判达成的债务上限法案中规定的 1.59 万亿美元低了约 1200 亿美元。

这些目标将使国防开支保持在债务上限立法商定的 8660 亿美元水平。但该计划将削减用于环境、公共援助和对外援助的支出。

它还将增加边境安全、禁毒执法和对抗中国的支出。

民主党人说，较低级别的人违背了债务上限协议。共和党人反驳说，该协议只是限制了支出。

“债务上限法案为 2024 财年的法案设定了上限，而不是下限。摆在我们面前的分配反映了我这边的议员希望看到的变化，”拨款委员会主席凯格兰杰说。

国会将争取在 10 月之前通过 12 项拨款法案，涵盖从执法到科学研究的方方面面。

周三，该小组通过了一项法案，该法案将把农业和食品药品管理局的开支从目前的水平上削减 30%。

该委员会的共和党人公布了另一项能源和水资源开发法案，民主党人称该法案将绿色能源激励等国内项目的支出削减 22%。

民主党人还反对共和党人在支出法案中附加的政策，例如防止堕胎药通过药店销售的政策。

较低的支出水平可能会使众议院更难与民主党领导的参议院达成协议。

如果参众两院无法在 10 月之前就支出水平达成一致，联邦机构可能不得不关闭。

“他们正朝着关闭的方向发展。这就是他们似乎想要保证的，”众议院民主党最高拨款代表罗莎德劳罗告诉路透社。

共和党代表史蒂夫沃马克也表达了对关闭的担忧。 "I worry about what's going to happen on Oct. 1," he said.

Reporting by David Morgan; editing by Andy Sullivan and Alistair Bell ; Thu, 15 Jun 2023 15:23:06 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/us/us-house-republicans-target-deeper-spending-cuts-raising-shutdown-threat-2023-06-15/ https://www.reuters.com/world/us/us-house-republicans-target-deeper-spending-cuts-raising-shutdown-threat-2023-06-15/David Morgan美国CONGRESS/REPUBLICANS Russia tries to signal normalcy as Ukraine forces advance

Russia announced plans on Thursday to stage elections in occupied parts of Ukraine in just three months, Moscow's latest bid to signal it is in control even as a Ukrainian counteroffensive has pushed its forces back in some areas.

The Ukrainian assault is in its early stages, and military experts say the decisive battles still lie ahead. But corpses of Russian soldiers and burnt-out armoured vehicles lining the roadside in villages newly recaptured by Ukrainian troops attested to Kyiv's biggest advances since last year.

Reuters reached the villages of Neskuchne and Storozheve over the past two days, providing the first independent confirmation of the Ukrainian advance several kilometres southwards along the Mokry Yali river into territory Russia had held since the early days of its invasion last year.

Several bodies of Russian soldiers lay in the streets of ruined and depopulated villages. Ukrainian troops in Storozheve told Reuters they had killed around 50 Russians and captured four there.

Moscow has not acknowledged any setbacks and says it has inflicted severe casualties on Ukrainians attempting to assault.

The Ukrainian military, which had maintained strict silence about the campaign for more than a week, came forward to tout the gains on Thursday, holding its first full media briefing since the counteroffensive began.

Troops had captured at least seven settlements and 100 square km (38 square miles) of territory in two major pushes in the south so far, Brigadier-General Oleksii Hromov said.

"We are ready to continue fighting to liberate our territory even with our bare hands," he said.

The army on the southern front had advanced by up to 7 km (4.4 miles) in the area along the Mokry Yali, as well as by up to 3 km (1.8 miles) on another axis further west near the village of Mala Tokmachka, Ukrainian military officials said.

They also described advances in the east around the ruined city of Bakhmut, which Moscow seized last month as its only major prize for a huge winter and spring offensive that saw the bloodiest ground combat in Europe since World War Two.

Russian President Vladimir Putin insisted this week that Moscow's goals in Ukraine remain unchanged despite the Ukrainian counteroffensive. He claimed that Russian forces were inflicting 10 times more casualties on Ukrainians than they were enduring.

ELECTION PLAN

Russia's announcement of a plan for elections in occupied territory was the latest effort by Moscow to convey that the situation was stable.

Russia's TASS state news agency quoted election chief Ella Pamfilova as saying that both the Defence Ministry and the Federal Security Service (FSB) had concluded that it would be possible to hold the votes in September.

Russia proclaimed its annexation of four Ukrainian provinces last year, although it does not fully control any of them and does not hold the main population centres of two.

Kyiv says any elections staged by Russians on Ukrainian territory would be invalid and illegal.

The big test of Ukraine's offensive still lies ahead . Russia has had months to prepare its defences. Ukrainian troops have yet to reach the heaviest Russian defensive fortifications, which are set back from the front line.

Kyiv is believed to have prepared an attack force of around 12 brigades of thousands of soldiers each, most using newly arrived Western armoured vehicles. Only a fraction of them have been engaged so far.

Russia, for its part, has released images of Western tanks and armoured vehicles it says it has destroyed or captured.

In Brussels, US Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin presided over the latest meeting of a group of around 50 countries, set up by Washington to coordinate donations of Western arms to Ukraine.

"I ask that the members of this contact group continue to dig deep to provide Ukraine with the air defence assets and munitions that it so urgently needs to protect its citizens," Austin said.

One of two female tourists attacked by a man near Neuschwanstein Castle in southern Germany has died, local media reported on Thursday citing state prosecutors.

A 21-year-old woman died in a hospital overnight, while her 22-year-old companion was still in hospital with serious injuries, the BR public broadcaster reported, citing a spokesperson for state prosecutors in Kempten.

A suspect has been arrested, BR quoted the spokesperson as saying. State prosecutors did not immediately reply to a request for comment.

BR cited prosecutors as saying that the women ran into a man on a bridge with a view of the world-famous castle and that he led them onto a trail.

BR reported that a scuffle ensued after the man sexually assaulted the 21-year-old. When the 22-year-old intervened, the man strangled her and threw her 50 metres into a ravine below, the report said.

He then strangled the 21-year-old and pushed her in as well, BR reported.

The suspect was caught after a massive police operation involving 25 emergency vehicles on Wednesday afternoon and taken to a police station in nearby Fuessen, it added.

Writing by Miranda Murray; Editing by Madeline Chambers and Conor Humphries ; Thu, 15 Jun 2023 13:17:44 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/tourist-dead-after-attack-near-germanys-neuschwanstein-castle-zdf-2023-06-15/ https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/tourist-dead-after-attack-near-germanys-neuschwanstein-castle-zdf-2023-06-15/Reuters德国CRIME/ (UPDATE 2) Pope Francis orders ex-aide of Pope Benedict to leave Vatican

Pope Francis has ordered Archbishop Georg Gaenswein, the private secretary and long-time aide of the late Pope Benedict, to return to his native Germany by the end of the month without any new assignment, the Vatican said on Thursday.

A Vatican statement put an end speculation about what role Gaenswein, a powerful figure in the Vatican for more than a decade before Francis sidelined him after a personal falling out, would have in the Church.

Former Pope Benedict died on Dec. 31, nearly a decade after he resigned in 2013, the first pontiff to do so in 600 years.

Gaenswein is 66 and it is exceptionally unusual for someone of that relatively young age and rank not to have an assignment, giving the pope's decision a sense of banishment.

The two-line statement said Francis "had disposed" that the 66-year-old Gaenswein return to his diocese of Freiburg "for the time being".

Nearly all papal secretaries in the past have either been assigned to lead dioceses or made cardinals or given some other high-profile post. Gaenswein is nine years short of the normal retirement age of 75 for bishops.

He has met Francis several times in the past months about his future and there has been speculation in Catholic media that he was hoping to land a diplomatic assignment as nuncio, or ambassador, to a country.

Gaenswein did not immediately respond to a request for comment on Thursday. He has refused requests from Reuters to comment on his situation in the past few weeks.

He was Benedict's personal secretary from 2003, when Benedict was still Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger, and remained at his side for nearly 20 years, nearly 10 of them after Benedict resigned.

In a book called "Nothing But The Truth - My Life Beside Benedict XVI" and sent to reporters by its publisher only hours after Benedict was buried on Jan. 5, Gaenswein rattled the Vatican by describing what he says were strains while two men wearing white lived within its walls.

Gaenswein and Francis fell out in 2020 when Gaenswein was at the centre of a messy episode concerning former Pope Benedict's role in a book about priestly celibacy that many saw as an attack on Francis' authority.

Reporting by Philip Pullella; editing by John Stonestreet and Toby Chopra ; Thu, 15 Jun 2023 11:46:26 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/pope-francis-orders-pope-benedict-ex-aide-leave-vatican-2023-06-15/ https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/pope-francis-orders-pope-benedict-ex-aide-leave-vatican-2023-06-15/Philip Pullella POPE BENEDICT/GAENSWEIN (UPDATE 1, PIX) Exclusive: Palau seeks more U.S. patrols of its waters after Chinese incursions

The Pacific island nation of Palau has asked the United States to step up patrols of its waters after several incursions by Chinese vessels into its exclusive economic zone, President Surangel Whipps Jr. told Reuters in an interview.

Whipps Jr. said he would also welcome a bigger US military presence in the country, with troops stationed alongside existing coastguard and civil action teams, as Washington and Beijing vie for influence in the strategic region.

"No matter what, we're going to be in the centre of whatever's happening, so it's important that we're protected," Whipps Jr. said during a visit to Tokyo on Wednesday, adding that "to get peace, you have to project strength".

The Pentagon did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

Asked about the incursions on Thursday, China's foreign ministry spokesperson Wang Wenbin said the vessels had taken shelter in the relevant waters and had not conducted any surveys or investigations. "Security cooperation between countries should not target third parties," he added.

Palau, a remote archipelago of coral and volcanic islands in the western Pacific home to just over 20,000 people, has a decades-old pact with Washington whereby the US retains responsibility for its defence and provides economic assistance - a legacy that has its roots in World War Two.

The US also has such pacts with the Pacific island states of Micronesia and the Marshall Islands, and struck a defence cooperation agreement with Papua New Guinea in May.

China has also been seeking to bolster its security presence in the Pacific, and last year penned a security pact with the Solomon Islands that alarmed the US, Australia and New Zealand.

REGIONAL FORUM PLEDGED TO TAKE UNITED POSITION

Palau identified Chinese vessels in its waters as recently as last month, when a ship appeared to be surveying an area near fibre optic cables vital to the country's communications, Whipps Jr. said.

He said he would raise the issue of the incursions at the regional Pacific Islands Forum leaders' meeting in November. The group has previously said it would take a united position on dealing with major powers, and last year rejected a push by China to sign a security and trade deal with 10 of its 18 members.

US Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin praised "small island states" like Palau in a speech in Singapore earlier this month and, in a 2021 meeting with Whipps Jr., expressed deep appreciation for the US-Palau partnership.

Palau has previously hosted US military exercises and the US plans to install over-the-horizon radar in the country by 2026.

During the multi-day trip to Japan, Whipps Jr. also visited the Fukushima Dai-ichi Nuclear Power Plant, which experienced a triple core meltdown from a tsunami triggered by a massive earthquake in 2011.

Japan is set to release a million tonnes of water starting this summer from the nuclear power plant into the Pacific Ocean. The water will have most of its radioactivity removed and be diluted to internationally approved levels but will still contain traces of tritium, an isotope that is difficult to separate from water.

The plan has been criticised by some local fishermen and neighbouring countries, including South Korea, China and some Pacific island nations.

But Whipps Jr. said he was not opposed to the plan and that he sensed regional resistance was also waning.

"We've made a decision that what they're doing is right and we should support them," he said.

Reporting by Sakura Murakami and John Geddie; Editing by Michael Perry and Alex Richardson ; Thu, 15 Jun 2023 09:24:13 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/palau-seeks-more-us-patrols-its-waters-after-chinese-incursions-2023-06-15/ https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/palau-seeks-more-us-patrols-its-waters-after-chinese-incursions-2023-06-15/Sakura Murakami, John Geddie PALAU USA/CHINA (UPDATE 1, EXCLUSIVE, PIX) Boris Johnson wilfully misled parliament, says UK report dubbed "rubbish" by ex-PM

Britain's Boris Johnson should be excluded from parliament for wilfully misleading lawmakers over rule-breaking COVID lockdown parties at his office, a committee said on Thursday in a damning report the former leader described as "rubbish".

In a more than 100-page report, the privileges committee - the main disciplinary body for lawmakers - said Johnson had wilfully mislead parliament on several occasions when he was asked about Downing Street gatherings during COVID-19 lockdowns.

The committee also accused Johnson of being "complicit in a campaign of abuse and attempted intimidation".

Johnson, one of Britain's most well-known and divisive politicians, shot back, repeating his innocence and condemning the report as "rubbish", "a lie" and "a charade", and accusing committee members of waging a vendetta against him.

In the report which details six events held at Downing Street, the committee, which has both members from the governing Conservatives and opposition Labour Party, said: "We conclude that in deliberately misleading the House Mr Johnson committed a serious contempt."

"We recommend that he should not be entitled to a former Member's pass," it added, referring to a pass which enables former prime minister's to gain access to parliament.

The Committee found that Johnson sought to undermine the parliamentary process by deliberately misleading the House of Commons and the Committee, by breaching confidence, impugning the Committee and by being complicit in a campaign of abuse and attempted intimidation.

It said that were Johnson still a member of parliament, it would have recommended a suspension from the House for 90 days.

Johnson resigned from parliament last week after seeing an advance copy of the report, calling the inquiry a "witch hunt", a criticism he double-downed on after its publication.

"I believed, correctly, that these events were reasonably necessary for work purposes. We were managing a pandemic," he said in a statement.

"But don't just listen to me. Take it from the Metropolitan Police. The police investigated my role at all of those events. In no case did they find that what I had done was unlawful."

Reporting by Elizabeth Piper, Kylie MacLellan, Muvija M and William James; Editing by Kate Holton ; Thu, 15 Jun 2023 08:32:33 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/uk/boris-johnson-wilfully-misled-parliament-says-uk-report-dubbed-rubbish-by-ex-pm-2023-06-15/ https://www.reuters.com/world/uk/boris-johnson-wilfully-misled-parliament-says-uk-report-dubbed-rubbish-by-ex-pm-2023-06-15/Elizabeth Piper, William James BRITAIN POLITICS/ (UPDATE 2) Greece hunts for survivors of migrant shipwreck, at least 78 dead

Rescuers scoured seas off Greece on Thursday in a massive search operation, as hopes dwindled of finding survivors of a shipwreck that killed at least 78 migrants in one of Europe's deadliest such disasters in recent years.

Reports suggested hundreds of people had packed the fishing boat that capsized and sank early on Wednesday in deep waters about 50 miles (80 km) from the southern coastal town of Pylos, while being shadowed by the Greek coast guard.

As dawn broke on Thursday, a coast guard vessel sailed into the nearby port city of Kalamata, transferring victims. After an official count, authorities revised the death toll to 78 from 79. They said 104 people were rescued.

They said it was unclear how many had been aboard, but were investigating one account from a European rescue-support charity that there could have been 750 people on the 20- to 30 metre-long (65- to 100-foot) boat.

The UN's International Organization for Migration said initial reports suggested up to 400 people were aboard.

News portal Proto Thema and Skai TV reported that, according to witnesses, mainly women and children were in the vessel's hold.

Government officials said migrants on the boat, which had set off from the Libyan port of Tobruk, had repeatedly refused offers of help from Greek authorities.

"It was a fishing boat packed with people who refused our assistance because they wanted to go to Italy," coast guard spokesperson Nikos Alexiou told broadcaster Skai TV.

"We stayed beside it in case it needed our assistance which they had refused."

NO ENGINE, NO CAPTAIN

The search operation was due to continue until at least Friday morning, according to government sources. Chances of retrieving the sunken vessel were remote, they said, because the area of international waters where the incident occurred is one of the deepest in the Mediterranean.

Aerial pictures released by the Greek coast guard showed dozens of people on the boat's upper and lower decks looking up, some with arms outstretched, hours before it sank.

Alarm Phone, which operates a trans-European network supporting rescue operations, said it received alerts from people on board a ship in distress off Greece late on Tuesday.

It said it had alerted Greek authorities and spoke to people on the vessel who estimated there were up to 750 people on board and appealed for help, and that the captain had fled on a small boat.

Government officials said that before capsizing and sinking around 2 am on Wednesday, the vessel's engine stopped and it began veering from side to side.

Greece is one of the main routes into the European Union for refugees and migrants from the Middle East, Asia and Africa.

Under a conservative government, in power until last month, authorities have taken a harder stance on migration, building walled camps and boosting border controls.

Greece's caretaker administration, in power between an inconclusive election on May 21 and new elections on June 25, declared three days of national mourning.

Libya, which has had little stability or security since a NATO-backed uprising in 2011, is a major launching point for those seeking to reach Europe by sea.

People-smuggling networks are mainly run by military factions that control coastal areas.

The United Nations has registered more than 20,000 deaths and disappearances in the central Mediterranean since 2014, making it the most dangerous migrant crossing in the world.

The government of Canadian Liberal Prime Minister Justin Trudeau wants to work with the newly elected conservative premier of the country's main oil-producing province, Alberta, to fight climate change, a federal minister said on Wednesday.

Natural Resources Minister Jonathan Wilkinson will meet Alberta Premier Danielle Smith on Monday for the first time since she won the election last month after campaigning on a promise to battle Ottawa's climate policies.

In her victory speech, Smith vowed to fight the federal government's proposed oil and gas emissions cap and clean electricity regulations. But on Tuesday she said in an interview with the Calgary Herald that she would "prefer collaboration."

Wilkinson told Reuters in a telephone interview that he "would certainly prefer to collaborate as well."

This first meeting is about "starting that positive conversation about how we can work together," he added.

The conciliatory tone may help Trudeau make progress on his climate agenda after Smith repeatedly attacked the federal government's "job killing" climate goals.

Canada is a laggard when it comes to cutting emissions, and Trudeau needs support from Alberta, Canada's highest-polluting province, to achieve his government's goals to cut carbon emissions 40-45% by 2030. Trudeau has staked his legacy on turning Canada and its oil-rich economy greener.

Smith released Alberta's first-ever climate plan in April, which targets net-zero emissions by 2050, but it does not have interim emissions-reduction targets.

The minister said the government is still working on the precise regulatory framework for a clean electricity grid by 2035 and the oil-and-gas emissions cap, and is looking for "thoughtful input and feedback as we move forward."

During her campaign, Smith railed against the high costs of shifting to a net-zero grid in just 12 years, but Wilkinson pointed toward the federal government's C$26 billion ($19.5 billion) investment tax incentives, introduced in this year's budget, to help utilities transition away from fossil fuels.

Grid reliability and transition costs "are legitimate concerns. And those are the things that I think we can work together on," the minister said. In the future, clean power will be vital to attract business "and that means that the grid is going to need to be clean."

Smith rejects the oil-and-gas cap entirely, saying it is a de facto production cap.

"What we want to do is ensure that ... the emissions reduction cap is technically feasible, but is a bit ambitious," Wilkinson said.

"We are reducing emissions in line with what needs to be done if we are to meet our scientifically driven climate goals. But we need to do so in a manner that is sensitive to regional economies," he said.

The minister's tone is different from the more adversarial one struck by the prime minister earlier this year.

"One of the challenges is there is a political class in Alberta that has decided that anything to do with climate change is going to be bad for them or for Alberta," Trudeau told Reuters in January.

Authorities in India's western state of Gujarat evacuated more than 75,000 people from vulnerable coastal communities as cyclone Biparjoy was expected whirl in from the Arabian Sea to make landfall by Thursday evening.

Early on Thursday, the cyclone was centred 180 km (112 miles) off Jakhau port in Gujarat and 270 km (168 miles) off Karachi in Pakistan, the India Meteorological Department said.

The storm appeared to have lost some of its intensity, and is expected to have a maximum sustained wind speed of 115-125 kmph (71-78 miles per hour) gusting to 140 kmph, down from the 150 kmph that the IMD had estimated on Wednesday.

"We have evacuated more than 75,000 persons from the eight coastal districts in Gujarat that are expected to be impacted by the cyclone," Kamal Dayani, additional chief secretary in Gujarat's revenue department said.

Temporary thatched houses could be completely destroyed while standing crops, plantations and roads were expected to face major damage, the IMD said in a statement on Wednesday, adding that railways could also face disruption.

Pakistan's Climate Change Minister Sherry Rehman said on Wednesday, Karachi, a port city of 20 million people, was not under immediate threat, but emergency measures were being taken to deal with winds and rain that are expected to batter the economic hub.
